p: During the early spring of 2013, a novel avian influenza A(H7N9) virus emerged to infect humans in eastern China and cause severe lower respiratory tract diseases [1]. Mainland China has experienced five epidemic waves of human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) virus infection. As of December 2019, a cumulative total of 1568 laboratory-confirmed cases and 616 deaths had been reported, primarily from China [2]. A surge in A(H7N9) cases was observed during the 5th epidemic wave of human infections, raising pandemic concerns [ 3, 4].
